description: From Middle English capcious, from Middle French captieux, or its source, Latin captiōsus, from captiō.

adjectives.description: captious (comparative more captious, superlative most captious)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) That captures; especially, (of an argument, words etc.) designed to capture or entrap in misleading arguments; sophistical.
Having a disposition to find fault unreasonably or to raise petty objections; cavilling, nitpicky.
examples: But Peter Petrovich did not accept this retort. On the contrary, he became all the more captious and irritable, as though he were just hitting his stride.
